Bedtime Story
Bedtime for the News-Letter this week found the
editors in a quandary. "There is no-one to hate," said
one. "There is certainly no call for Kudos," said the
other. What to do? What to do?
You, the reader, are responsible for our editorial
position, so to speak, here in this quandary. You have
not sent us letters brimming with incendiary rhetoric,
launched raids on the Goucher unmentionables, or
erected a 1200 pound phallic symbol in the dormitory
quadrangle. Neither have you done anything legitimately
laudable.
The administration seems to have placed its activities above the range of N-L criticism, and has everything moving along quite smoothly, or at least in a
fashion that does not warrant discussion.
Allow us, therefore, in this moratorium on excitement, to offer a few lame volleys, eclectic of aim:
The Homewood has again surpassed all previous
years in both quality and quantity of feminine pulchritude on the scene, and we hope that everything we say
will he held against us. Woman. Woman, when well
done, is the only physical beauty at the Hop, and
the MAT program is the undergraduate's greatest benefactor.
One should certainly think that large scale improvements would include the addition of a few wellplaced soft-drink machines on campus and improved
quality in the Food Service food, but if one should
think this, one would be making a grave mistake. The
only science for which this university does not have
an overweaning concern is gastronomy.
Renovation plans for Gilman Hall include enlarged quarters for the bank and bookstore. We hope
an adjacent area might also be enlarged to provide
for comfort of the eternal line at the hank. The bookstore's increased size might be of financial benefit
to patrons, as prices will no doubt he reduced when
Mr. Vayne finds that he can spread his costs over a
greater area.

BG or LBJ?
There is a surprisingly small amount of political
'discussion on this campus. We have a well informed
student body, but few people care to discuss the Presidential race.
Those who support Barry Goldwater are too busy
trying to figure out just where he stands today to argue
with Johnson supporters.
Johnson supporters are too busy trying to work
tip enthusiasm among themselves for their man to argue
with Goldwater supporters.
The only widespread enthusiasm seems to be not
for anything or anybody, but rather against Barry
Goldwater. Most people say they agree with Goldwater
that motherhood, apple pie, and freedom are good.
These same people, however, insist that they be allowed
to enjoy those desirable things over the course of a
normal life span.

On Courses
Few freshmen realize the extent of the riches of
This school. There are vast intellectual resources here,
and they are always available, waiting for someone who
is intellectually hungry to come along and tap them.
Finding these resources is not hard: all it takes
Is the strength and common sense needed to take difficult, challenging courses. These are the courses given
by the really good professors on campus, and these are
the courses that are talked about in the halls or at dinner.
There is a wonderful intellectual give and take in
these courses. Students find that a really good professor incessantly probes their minds, showing them the
riches of their intelligences. And students find themselves, in thet process, incessantly probing the mind of
such a professor.
The minds of professors and students are the basic
resource of a university. A student who is not willing
or strong enough to develop his own mind and take
advantage of the minds of others will find that he has
wasted a large sum of money in coming to Ilopkins.
Perhaps, later he will have regrets, for rarely, if ever,
will he again find the concentrated intellectual resources
available on the Homewood campus.

The recent Civil Rights Act is
neither a cure-all nor a mere
political gimmick; rather it is a
small step toward the emancipation of the American soul. I
have no doubt as to its necessity
or constitutionality; it merely
guarantees certain basic human
rights too long denied to too
many Americans.

In recent years, the need for
some sort of government action
on the Negro question has become
apparent. The problem arises for
the conservative of finding a
solution which would work within the governmental limitations
imposed by the Constitution and
which would in no large way endanger the traditional liberties
then shared by all Americans.
The first question arising in
this connection is concerned
with the nature of the problem,
that is its sources and causes.
It is also important, lest the risk
be run of condemning a sizable
portion of the American population as hopeless, immoral bigots,
to understand the feelings of the
people involved—both black and
white. The conservative approach
would from the beginning assume that the problem in different areas is different by nature and tradition and would
treat the problem accordingly.
The answer to the first question can be answered simply that
the Negro has been denied broad
access to the cultural and economic opportunities in this country. The problem is centered in
the South, since those Negroes
who are not in the South have
probably come from the South
during this century. The problem is broader than the Negro
and must include the poor whites.
The people are victims of misunderstandings and have reached
seemingly logical conclusions
concerning the Negro. With this
comes the first apparent means
of attackng the problem. This attack should be centered in the
realm of public information and
public opinion. The President is
in a position to influence public
opinion in a large way, and if
this is not sufficient, it may become necessary to provide a public information service to deal
with the problem.
Further, since the problem is
centered in the South, the problem in the South must be considered apart from the problem
in the rest of the country. On
examination, it will be found
that the South is suffering under
the burden of many more problems. The majority of all
